titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. I wrote and sent to Count Romanzoff, a letter as he requested— After dinner, and in the Evening I wrote also part of a letter to the Secretary of State— This is all that I could do by making myself very busy during the whole continuance of day-light; and even by forcing myself to write some hours by candle light— Mr: Harris informs me of an opportunity to send by the way of England next week— When I am much occupied with other affairs I necessarily fall in arrears with my journal.

2. Rising late, I could not even finish my letter to the Secretary of State by day-light— I began reading the volume of Massillon’s Advent Sermons— The first is for all Saints day; upon the happiness of the righteous— A comparison between a worldly life, and a life of Sanctity— It is better written than most of those upon the Panegyrics but the same style of Sentiment, and the same general ideas so continually recur, that it seems like reading over again the same Sermons— I read also Robinson’s character of David. It is very long and employed me all the Evening— A black man, named Thomas Baker came to me this morning for relief— He belongs to the ship of Captain Symonds at Archangel— The Captain took him there to bring him with him as a servant, and left him about half way on the road— I gave him directions by which he might endeavour to find a place

3. Mr: Navarro paid me a long visit this morning; and told me that the day before yesterday the answer was given to the French Ambassador declining the adoption of the measures recommended by France, with regard to colonial articles, and English Manufactures— And as to the demand that all the frenchmen in the military service of this Country should be dismiss’d; the french Emperor’s decree making this an offence capitally punishable, has been by the Emperor’s Alexander’s order communicated to each of the french Officers in his service; but they have not been dismiss’d— This Evening I paid a visit to Mr: Bridge & Mr: Patterson, and also at Mr: Krehmer’s; but found none of them at home— I went alone to a Ball at Count Bussche’s— And after walking the Polonaise with Madame de Vlodek, her Sister Countess Tolstoy, and Madame Lesseps the french Consuls wife, and looking on the other dancers a couple of hours I came home— The french Ambassador received a Courier while there and left the Company.

4. Rose this morning before the Sun, and took a walk of five miles before breakfast— The Sun rises now precisely at 9 O’Clock, and sets at three— The black man who had been to me yesterday and the day before came again, and can find no place. I agreed therefore for the present to take him into my service— Mr: Montréal called and paid me a visit— I walked again as the dusk of Evening came on; that is between 3 and 4 O’Clock— Met the Emperor walking on the English Quay— He stop’d and made some remarks upon the weather— Messrs: Patterson, Bridge, Fisher and J. S. Smith dined and spent the Evening with us— Mr: Harris was engaged, and by a mistake of Pierre’s, Mr: Jones was not asked. Mr: Harris called upon me however in the course of the morning— We spent the Evening at Cards.

5. I was employed all this morning in making up packets for America, to be sent to Mr: Pinkney at London, by a Gentleman who is going to England.— Received a Notification from the Grand-Master of the Ceremonies Narishkin, that there would be a diplomatic Circle to-morrow at Noon it being the name day of the Grand Duchess Catherine and the festival of the order of St: Catherine— (Mrs: Krehmer and her daughter spent the Evening and supp’d with us. Mr: Jones & Mr: Smith were also here. Mrs: Krehmer told Mrs: Adams that the Emperor had seen a letter of Martha Godfrey’s to her Sister, written last Winter in which she spoke of this Country severely, and that was the reason why he had been curious to see Martha, and was the occasion of Charles’s being sent for to visit the Princess Amelia.)— I should have mentioned on the 2d: that Baron Schladen the Prussian Minister called upon me, with Mr: Jouffroy, whom he presented to me as his Secretary of Legation just arrived.

6. At twelve O’Clock I went with the two Messrs: Smith to the Winter Palace, where we found the diplomatic body already assembled and in the Hall of the throne— I spoke to Count Romanzoff about the letter I had written him, which he told me he had read to the Emperor, and that he had permitted him to refer it immediately to the Minister of Commerce.— Count Maistre told a story of a french Lady who paid a high compliment to a Judge of the Parliament of Paris, who was an excellent performer on the violin— Comment—mais c’est le premier violon du Parlement— The Count said that Ladies ought never to say such things; for they stuck by a man all his life time— The Emperor and Empresses came into the Hall earlier than usual— The Emperor spoke to me about my walking—he said that General Pardo and I were two of the steadiest that he knew— The Empress asked me about her old acquaintance Charles; and the Empress Mother about my children in America— Count St: Julien took the place next to the Ambassador in the Circle, and Baron Blome was not there— Before two O’Clock the Circle was over— I paid visits to Countess Litta, and to the Grand Marechal Count Tolstoy, whose wife and daughter are both Catherine’s, and sent Cards to the Grand Master of the Ceremonies whose wife bears the same name— It is a rule of etiquette to pay visits to every body of your acquaintance on their name-days.— Mr: J. S. Smith dined with us, and Mr: Harris was here in the Evening— We sat at Cards untill quite late.

7. Mr: Gray called on me this morning with Mr: Woodward, supercargo, of one of his fathers vessels, arrived at Baltic-Port— Mr: Woodward asked advice about the house which is to transact his business; but he had already been to Messrs: Meyer & Brüxner; and written to them— I considered him as so far engaged that I advised him not to go to another house. I spent the whole of this day at home excepting the time of my walk to the foundery. Mrs: Adams and Catherine pass’d the Evening at Genl: Betancourt’s. I read Levesque Vol 4. and have at length come to the reign of Peter the Great.— To continue the practice of short hand, and to improve my reading of the Bible, I have begun to write some reflexions upon it which I can continue occasionally; if I have resolution and perseverance to that end.

8. I called this morning upon Mr: Navarro who lent me a copy of the treaty of Tilsit and promised to procure for me a copy of the act of Confederation of the Rhine— After 9 this Evening we had Cards with the Ladies and Mr: Gray.— I had before been writing in short hand— I pass’d the day at home, excepting the walk round the Fontanka and the Quay.

9. Mr: Fisher called on me this morning; with Captain Hayes, master of the Reward, one of the American vessels lately arrived at Baltic-Port, and which meet with demur in obtaining their admission— Mr: Harris was here afterwards and is alarmed at some remarks lately made to him by Mr: Borel— Mr: Jones dined with us. Mr: J. S. Smith, Mr: Paterson and Mr: Tilden pass’d part of the Evening here; but I did not see them— I was in my Cabinet reading Massillon’s Sermon upon All-Souls day— And Robinson’s characters of Solomon and Ahab— The Sermon is very good— A Contrasted view of the Death of the righteous and that of the Sinner— The portraiture of the Sinner’s Death-bed is almost equal to Reynolds’s Cardinal Beaufort, from Shakespear—

10. Mr: Harris and Mr: J. S. Smith dined and passed the Evening with us— We spent it at Cards— Mr: Harris however has had another Conversation with Mr: Borel, from which he as is again full of confidence, as to the issue of affairs in question here at this time concerning America.

11. Although I was not interrupted by any visitors this day, I wrote but little; having neglected to employ the few hours of day-light according to their destination— Mr: Grammann sent me some English Newspapers to 6. November, which diverted my attention from my business— In the Evening, I copied a page in short hand from the Treaty of Tilsit, and finished reading the fourth Volume of Levesque’s History.

12. I intended to have made up this day for the deficiencies of yesterday’s industry; but visits in succession from Mr: Harris, Mr. Montreal, Mr: W. B. Adams from Archangel, and Mr: Woodward occupied the day from breakfast-time untill dark. I went with Mr: Woodward, and introduced him to Mr: Raimbert and Mr: Montréal— Walk’d from 3 to 5. Mr: W. Smith dined abroad. I pass’d the Evening at home— Finished copying the Treaty of Tilsit; and read untill 10 in the Evening the 5th: volume of Levesque’s History. It contains the account of the horrible prosecution of Alexei by his father Peter the first.

13. Visit this morning from Mr: Raimbert. Mr: Plincke, my landlord called, and we executed a lease for two years from the first of June last the time when we came into the house—it is stipulated in this lease as is customary here that the rent shall always be paid six months in advance— I therefore paid Mr: Plincke six thousand Rubles in Bank paper, for a year’s rent, including fire-wood— This and some other domestic concerns employed my time so that Evening came on before I had finished the letter which I have been writing these four days— On returning from my daily walk, I found that Mrs: Adams had been suddenly seized, and was very ill— She continued so all the Evening— Mr: Jones & Mr: J. S. Smith were here in the Evening. The Gentlemen all went to the French Ambassadors masked Ball— I did not go; and sent an excuse by Mr: W. Smith.— I wrote Short hand, but read none.

14. Mr: Harris called on me this morning; and some domestic concerns which employ too much of my time engaged the hours of daylight; so that I could not finish my letter— Mr: Smith was out the whole day— In the Evening Mr: Plummer spent about three hours with me— I had read a few pages of Levesque, but could not resume it, after he went away— I have suspended writing any further reflections upon the Bible for the present— I find so much that I do not understand and so much that I do not comprehend, that I am afraid of writing things useless or worse— I want Books to explain to me many of the obscurities— I feel a restraint upon me in expressing my whole thought, and a fear of committing to paper my own errors and ignorance, though in cypher— But as a continuation of my exercises in short hand, I began a sketch of memoirs of my own life, which I have long been in the intention of writing for the use of my children— This is a work which if it please the father of Spirits to give me the faculties necessary to accomplish it as it should be written may be hereafter useful to my Country and to mankind as well as to my Children— My life has indeed nothing in it to dazzle or to excite the attention of the world— But its scenery has been variegated; its adventures have been often curious and its results could they be indicated with sagacity, and enlivened by the charm of imagination would be instructive— My first prayer is for perseverance in the pursuit— My plan is not matured— At present however I shall assume the principle which I pursued in the composition of my Lectures, of writing in the first sketch whatever occurs to my mind, to alter enlarge and retrench, at the second Copy as my judgment shall dictate.

15. Mr: W. B. Adams called again upon me this morning, and asked me to procure a Courier’s Passport for him, and Mr: Strong, they are going to Gothenburg; where Mr Adams intends to embark for America— As I propose to send despatches by him I promised him to apply for a Passport for him— Mr: Montréal was here in the morning— Mr: J. S. Smith dined with us. I finished at last the letter which I have been nearly a week, writing— In the Evening I wrote Short-hand, and read Levesque vol 5. Finished the reign of Peter the first and was much disappointed on finding that he gives nothing but a short summary of the succeeding reigns. He is in general favourable to the Russians, but not so much so to Peter as Voltaire.

16. I wrote to Count Romanzoff requesting a Couriers Passport for Mr: W. B. Adams, and I wrote also a letter to Mr: Gray at Boston. The day was already gone— In walking before dinner, I met the Emperor, who did not know me untill after I had pass’d him. Mr: Harris dined and pass’d the Evening with us. Mrs: Adams was so unwell as not to dine with us at table— I read Massillon’s Sermon for the first Sunday of Advent— On the day of Judgment—very eloquent, but greatly open to controversy—of that day and hour knoweth no Man— I also read Robinson’s Character of Jehosaphat; & sat up late, writing.

17. Mr: Montréal was with me this morning and Mr. Harris in the Evening— Mr: Delapré the keeper of the house at the Ville de Bordeaux was here— I engaged him to furnish us our dinners, at a stated price—twenty Rubles a day. And I shall dismiss my Cook— When a family becomes large, there is no possibility of observing economy in it, without the closest attention to minute details. Since we entered this house my monthly expence books have been insensibly swelling untill they amount to double what they were the first month. We have a Maitre d’Hotel, or Steward— A Cook who has under him two Scullions— Moozhiks. A Swiss or Porter. Two footmen— A Moozhik to make the fires. A Coachman and Postillion—and Thomas the Black man, to be my valet de chambre— Martha Godfrey the maid we brought with us from America— A femme de chambre of Mrs: Adams, who is the wife of the Steward A House-Maid and a Laundry maid.— The Swiss, the Cook, and one of the footmen are married; and their wives all live in the house— The Steward has two Children, and the washerwoman a daughter; all of whom are also kept in the house.— I have Bakers, Milkmans, Butcher’s, Greenman’s, poulterers, and fishmonger’s & grocer’s bills, to pay monthly; besides purchases of tea, Coffee, sugar, wax and tallow candles— The fire-wood is luckily included as part of my Rent. On all these articles of Consumption the Cook and Steward, first make their profits on the purchase, and next make free pillage of the articles themselves— The Steward takes the same liberty with my wines— In dismissing my Cook I shall attempt to escape from a part of these depredations— To avoid a great part of them is impossible— It is I believe the law of Nature between Master and Servant, that the Servant shall spoil or plunder the Master— In this Country at least it is universal usage— It requires the most constant and minute attention to keep this pilfering within tolerable bounds; and among the losses occasioned by it, the most valuable is the loss of time; swallowed up in the baseness of such drudgery. It engaged me so much of this day that I had only time left to write to my mother; and to that I was obliged to devote the evening as well as the day.

18. Mr. Adams called on me this morning, and I engaged him to wait untill the end of the week before he leaves the City— It being by the Russian Calendar the festival of St: Nicolas, and Count Romanzoff’s name-day, I left a Card at his house— Visited also at Baron Schladen’s, and at Count St: Julien’s; but neither of them was at home— Mr: J. S. Smith, Mr: Adams and Mr: Woodward dined with us— Mr: Everett & Mr: Gray dined abroad— In the Evening we had a visit from General Watzdorf, the Saxon Minister— The Evening therefore was given to Company— I rose this morning, and read an hour by candle-light—that is at half past 8 O’Clock— Yet I could not in the course of the day finish a short letter to Dr: Mitchill— Mr: Navarro came, and gave me his despatches for England. I asked General Watzdorf for letters for Mr: Smith; which he promised.

19. Mr: Rodde was here this morning, and is going to-morrow for Riga— He had been with Baron Campenhausen to enquire concerning the vessels arrived at the outports, and which are not yet admitted to enter, or dispose of their Cargoes— The Baron promises that the business shall be decided next week. Mr: Rodde asked me for a letter to Mr: Gray at Boston, in favour of a Mr: Seymour who is going to travel in the United States; which I promised him and accordingly sent him in the Evening. Mr: Navarro called again, and read me the whole of his correspondence with Count Romanzoff concerning the Treaty between this Country and Portugal. He also told me of the Council held the day before yesterday, and of its result. I finished my letter to Dr: Mitchill and wrote also to Dr: Waterhouse— Received from Count Romanzoff, the Courier’s Passport and order for horses for Mr: W. B. Adams accompanied by Benjn: H. Strong; and two very large packages for Count Pahlen. In the Evening I wrote again a note to Count Romanzoff, mentioning Mr: J. S. Smith’s intention of going away, and his desire to be presented to their Imperial Majestys to take leave. Requesting also letters for him to the Russian Ministers at Berlin, Dresden, Vienna or Paris— Mr: Bridge and Mr: Fisher were here— And Mr: Bridge asked me to see and speak with Baron Campenhausen about the ships— Mr: W. S. Smith dined abroad.

20. I called this morning before breakfast, at about 11. O’Clock upon Baron Campenhausen, and had a Conversation of two hours with him, on the subject of the American vessels, which are waiting for admission at the Ports of Revel, Baltic-Port, Riga, and Liebau— He received me with politeness, but complained that he had been for a fortnight very unwell with a rhumatism,
and unable to go out of his house— I mentioned to him the subject of my visit. Told him of the letter which I had written more than a fortnight since to Count Romanzoff on this subject— That I was now about to dispatch a Courier to Gothenburg to embark there for the United States, and that I was desirous of informing the Government what the ultimate decision concerning these vessels and their Cargoes would be—that Mr: Rodde had called upon me yesterday, after having been with him, and mentioned to me that there were some Circumstances which had occasioned suspicions in his (Baron Campenhausen’s) mind, which perhaps it might be in my power to explain to his satisfaction— He said that with regard to the vessels there was no question or difficulty— But that with respect to the Cargoes, the Emperor had ordered a special examination and determination to be made upon the sixty-seven vessels which had arrived at the out-ports since the close of the Navigation here— That they belonged to a Convoy, about which a great deal had been said— And after several of them had been admitted; it was found that one of them had two sets of Papers; by one of which she had entered as coming only from Gothenburg, and by the other she appeared to have come from Fernambouco— The Emperor had therefore directed that a special examination and comparison of the papers of all these vessels should be made— That of the American vessels some had all the papers in order, and with regard to them there would be no difficulty— Some wanted papers for part of their Cargoes; and some for the whole— Some had certificates that their goods came from Calcutta, and one from Marie-Galante— That the laws of the Country were express and positive, as to the papers required; and if any were admitted which were not provided with those papers it must be by special indulgence— I observed that I supposed the only paper required by law, of which these vessels would be destitute would be the certificates of origin from the Russian Consuls, and the cause of their wanting them was that they had been originally destined for other Ports than those of Russia—for the Ports of Denmark or of Prussia; and they came here only in consequence of finding themselves excluded from them— That two vessels under the same Circumstances had been admitted more than two months since, on a representation which I had made to him and to Count Romanzoff; and that I had considered that as a precedent which would apply in all other cases of the same description— That, he said could not be concluded, for in those cases the decision was by the special order of the Emperor himself— They were solitary cases of exception from the rigour of the law; but now it had become necessary to decide upon the general principle; which the Emperor had thought proper to refer to the council; and my letter to Count Romanzoff had also been referred to the same body; together with the other papers.— But he said it was rather hard upon Russia, to have such an immense mass of foreign merchandizes, thus thrown upon her in a manner, after the navigation season was closed—especially in the unfavourable state of her exchange— I told him I was very glad he had given me this intimation, because it would give me an opportunity of suggesting to him several considerations which appeared to me both equitable and important in favour of my own Countrymen— I should not contest the correctness of his principle that the export trade should be encouraged more than that of imports— It was natural and reasonable that every Country should wish to have the general balance of trade in her favour, and should frame her commercial laws at home upon that foundation— It was my duty to speak only of the portion of trade carried on between Russia, and my own Countrymen— That on the trade carried on by the Americans here, the balance was in favour of Russia and I could not suppose it would be insisted that we should bring nothing but money in payment of the articles of Russian produce and manufacture which we come to take— He said he could not conceive how the balance should be in favour of Russia, when the ships came almost all laden with colonial articles, one Cargo of which would pay for more than three return Cargoes of any Russian Articles— I told him, I must with submission question the correctness of his estimate— I owned that generally speaking the Russian Exports were more bulky than the Colonial Articles, for corresponding values, and perhaps if he supposed hemp to be the only article exported, it might take three Cargoes of that to pay for a rich Cargo of Colonial wares. But if he would take the manufactured articles as the standard, the proportion would be far more equal, and an import Cargo, would certainly not pay for two return Cargoes of the same burthen— He instanced Indigo— But I told him that could in the nature of things form but a small part of the imported Articles— No vessel would be laden with it entirely— Of very few Cargoes indeed would it form a large proportion. Besides which I added that many American vessels came here in ballast; and went home laden to the
amount of 3 or 400000 Rubles. Many American Merchants who had balances left after the sale of the Cargoes which they sent here, and the loading of their vessels in return, left the balance in the hands of their correspondents to be vested in the funds of the Country, or in goods to be exported the ensuing season which contributed to support the prices of the Articles, at times when otherwise there would be scarcely any sales for them at-all— From the very nature of the trade between the United States, and this Country, it must be the interest of the Americans who carried it on, to load their vessels with the richest Cargoes of Russian manufactures that they could carry, that they might make a profit on the homeward as well as on the outward voyage— That certainly there was no gold or silver carried from this Country to America— But he said it was the same thing if the money was paid by remitting Bills— There was no profit I replied in making remittances; for whatever the rate of exchange was, by taking a Bill on London or Amsterdam, a man would never get more than the worth of his money in the market; while by exporting a Cargo of goods he would always calculate upon a suitable commercial profit to be made upon them— The distance of the United States; the necessary length and expense of the voyage made this profit a more essential object to the merchant— The opening of the trade to South-America, and the Spanish West-India islands, had naturally much increased the trade between the United States and Russia— Those Countries consumed great quantities of the Russian manufactures; more even than North-America. We took from them their productions, and carried them those of Russia in return— The Baron said that au reste, these were political considerations which ought not to operate in the case of the vessels in question; for if they had come in conformably to the laws of the Country, they could not at any rate be subjected to the rejection of their Cargoes on mere views of policy— He asked me if I had seen an Article in the Gazettes; a letter from Elseneur, in which it was denied in the strongest terms that there were any American vessels in this Convoy at Gothenburg— It seemed he said as if the American Government itself ought to take notice of such charges as those— I did not at first understand to what Article he alluded; but when he explained it, I told him, yes, I had seen that Article, which was dated at Elseneur, but which I presumed he knew was fabricated at Paris— That in pretending there were no Americans among that fleet at Gothenburg it had certainly made a false statement— That perhaps there might be in the fleet some vessels which had assumed the American flag, without being entitled to it; but as the fleet consisted of about seven hundred sail; and I did not know of more than twenty-five or thirty Americans among them, the proportion of real Americans to the whole number was certainly very small— He asked me what was the reason that American vessels had been excluded from the Prussian and Danish Ports— I told him, because the Governments of those Countries had been required to pass ordinances to that effect, by an authority which they could not resist— That I need not tell him it was an act involuntary and reluctant on their part— But the kings of Prussia and of Denmark were to be pitied rather than blamed for the rigours extorted from them, and which it could not be supposed would have been exercised by them, if they retained the sentiment or the pretension to Independence— He asked me what could be the motive of France for this rigour— I told him that France had undertaken to levy a duty of fifty per Cent upon most of the Articles which were brought by American vessels— If the same Articles could have been freely imported into Denmark & Prussia upon the payment of moderate duties; the french Government could not with all its power have prevented the introduction of them by contraband into France, and therefore could not have raised that enormous and oppressive duty. France too entertains the opinion that she cannot injure commerce of any kind without injuring England; and provided she can strike England cares not through whose sides the thrust is made.— But was there not a great abuse (he asked) of the American flag made by the English—did not they counterfeit papers— Mr: Harris himself had written him last Summer that he could not vouch for the authenticity of any papers relating to Cargoes; and there had been for instance a vessel arrived at Archangel entered as from Gothenburg, and which for sometime appeared to have papers perfectly in order— But afterwards another set of Papers had been found— She had been dispatched from Dublin; and even the Instructions to the Captain were found, in what cases he was to produce one set of papers, and when the other— I said there were undoubtedly cases of that kind; and there were Americans as there were individuals of all other Nations, who would practice any imposition which could bring them profit— They were however
few in number, and easily detected— Less frequent indeed than those instances of English forgeries presenting themselves in the semblance of American ship papers, which had been exposed and denounced by the American Consul himself; and for the exposure of which I had not escaped the obloquy of the English public Journals— He asked what could have become of all the vessels of that convoy from Gothenburg, if there were really seven hundred of them— I said he would find if he consulted the Gazettes which he had mentioned to me, that a great number had been captured and would be confiscated by the Danes. That some had come to the Russian Ports, and that all the rest had perished in Tempests— But that if he chose to send a messenger round to all the harbours of the Baltic as far as Gothenburg and on both its shores, I imagine he would find there had been very abundant salvages from all these wrecks. I would of course not be understood as now speaking of the Russian Ports— But setting them aside it was a very generally received opinion among the merchants that notwithstanding all the manifestations of rigour against every thing English which were resounding throughout Europe, it was not an impossible thing by a suitable sacrifice of an adequate sum of money, and a judicious application of it, English property, and English vessels under whatever disguise might even now obtain admission into many Ports of the North. I said this was what had been mentioned to me by some of my Countrymen as the most extraordinary circumstance in its appearance to them; and that even in the difficulties which they had met with at Archangel, they had seen other vessels far less entitled to admission than theirs according to the intention of the Laws obtain that admission with apparent facility— He smiled and said he supposed there might be some such cases; but that they must have escaped detection by the apparent regularity of all their papers— That, I replied was probable; and indeed it was obvious that those who were deliberately practising fraud and imposition would be most punctiliously correct to every formality— He said that the certificates produced for some of the goods in these Cargoes stated them as coming from Calcutta; and others from Marie Galante— That Calcutta was altogether an English Possession, and that the certificates might as well have been from London—that Marie-galante having been formerly a possession of France, it might be a question whether the goods had been exported from the island before or since it had been taken by the English, and it seemed incumbent on the importers here to furnish proof that it was before— I asked him whether he was certain that the papers of the former kind certified the goods as from Calcutta; or in general terms as from India— That he said was another and a distinct question. There were some from India, but those he had referred to expressly mentioned Calcutta— I told him I had heard of both the cases, and had reflected upon them, as certainly they presented under the existing laws of the Empire questions deserving of very mature reflection— That the Commerce of the United States with India, even with Bengal, was so far from being justly considered as English, that it was a rival trade to that of the English; and carried on with the People of the Country— That our vessels had been admitted into the Ports of the British Settlements there by virtue of an Article in our Treaty with England of 1794; and that we had not since been excluded from them; but that on a late Negotiation for the renewal of this Treaty, the English Government had refused to renew that Article, on the urgent representations of the East-India Company who have the monopoly of the trade with India in England, and who complained that our competition there was ruinous to them.— As to the articles from Marie-Galante, the fair presumption was that their exportation must have been previous to the occupation of the island by the British, because it might be taken as a general rule that the moment a West-India Island became a British Possession, our vessels, and those indeed of all other Nations but themselves were excluded from them— But said he, did you not just tell me that you were admitted to their Colonies in India? do they make a distinction between the East and the West?— I said they did—that in the same Treaty of 1794 that I had just mentioned, there had originally been inserted an Article by which our vessels were to be partially and conditionally admitted to their West-India Islands— But the condition had appeared so burthensome to our own Government that the Treaty had been ratified with the exception of that Article; and therefore our vessels are never admitted to their islands in the West-Indies, except when to save the inhabitants of the islands themselves from famine, their Governors allow us to come for three or six months at a time, by special proclamations— Returning then to the goods from Calcutta, he said that he thought the importers should at least have produced proof, that they were not of English produce or manufacture— I told him that if he would permit me between him and me, in perfect confidence, and with the assurance that
that it should operate no disadvantage to the persons interested, I could tell him that they did possess the proof, which he thought should be required of them— Why then did they not produce it?— Because it was contained in a document perfectly authentic; but which the french Government had thought proper to declare to be false— Oh! said he, I understand you—it is the certificate of the French Consuls— Well, they are right not to exhibit that— Finally he assured me that the business should be decided in a very few days— Certainly by the beginning of the next week. That every thing on his part was ready, and the Council would have decided upon it some days since; but that other business of importance had taken up all their time. He urged me strongly to detain the Courier two or three days longer, which at this Season he thought could not be of much consequence; for so long a journey and voyage— This too he said had been one occasion of the delays in the decision— Because at any rate the vessels could not get away for some months, and that a delay of some days could be no material injury to them. I observed to him that all delays might seriously affect them in the disposal of their Cargoes, and in their negotiations for a return Cargo— They could do nothing while the question about their admission was in suspence— Besides which there was a Circumstance which it might require some delicacy for me properly to mention— But my Countrymen upon arriving here applied to merchants to assist them in transacting their business— The moment a difficulty in relation to their papers occurred, it was suggested to them, that the way must be smoothed by a payment of money; which I believe was sometimes charged when it was not paid— He said he thought persons who were capable of such a thing ought to be exposed— That in the ordinary cases at the Custom-House, or before the neutral Commission, there might be some use of money—there might be some bad men, (mauvais sujets) there, whom it was impossible to detect; but in this case he could assure me there was no occasion for money, and could be nothing obtained by it— The Commission or Custom-house had nothing to do with it— The Emperor had ordered it for a special decision of the Council, and money was out of the question— He again repeated the request that I would detain the Courier two or three days longer; and said that as to the greater part of the Cargoes they would certainly be admitted; and as to the rest said he; we will try and find some expedient to let them in too. I finally consented to detain the Courier untill Tuesday or Wednesday; though I told him I should have to apologize to Count Romanzoff, from whom I had already received the Passports and his own despatches for the Minister of His Majesty in the United States— I left the Baron after a Conversation of about two hours.— Two Gentlemen of his friends came in about half an hour before I had finished— But finding us engaged they pass’d into another room untill I came away— It was about one O’Clock, when I got home to breakfast— Mr: Harris was here immediately afterwards— I had agreed to go this day with him, and dine at Count Stedingk’s; but wishing to write in the Evening, I thought best to postpone it. Mr: Harris dined with us. Mr: Adams also called on me, and agreed to delay his departure untill next Tuesday or Wednesday.

21. Visits this morning from Mr: Lohman, and from Mr: Navarro. Mr: Lohman who wishes to go to England, and who is desirous of obtaining a Courier’s Passport, is now perplexed in what manner to proceed—whether to Gothenburg, or by the way of France— I told him I would speak to the French Ambassador, and ascertain whether there would be any difficulty to his going from France to England— Mr: Navarro brought me his Packet to go by Mr: Strong; and gave me some further particulars about the imperial Council held last Monday— I went to the sleigh-makers shops of which there is a row in the Newsky Perspective, beyond the Fontanka—and purchased a sleigh— The remainder of the day and evening I was engaged in writing; without however accomplishing much— Charles has been there two days quite unwell with a Cold and Cough— Mr: J. S. Smith dined with us.

22. General Watzdorf came this morning, and offered a Passport for Mr: J. S. Smith; which he said he might possibly have occasion for in traveling through Saxony. He sat with me about an hour and conversed freely upon general political topics. In taking my usual walk, I met the Emperor on the Fontanka quay— He said he knew me again with my hat, and that he had several times pass’d me without knowing me from the changes of dress on my head— He asked me if I was not afraid of heating my head too much by the use of the fur-cap— I told him no—I wore it only in very cold weather, and then my
head was so much uncovered by Nature, that the fur was not too much for it. He asked me if he had not seen Mrs: Adams (Madame) pass just now in a sleigh— I told him he had— Was she not afraid of riding thus in the open air; on account of her health?— I said it had been recommended to her, by her physician— Who was her physician?— Dr: Galloway— He said that Dr: Galloway was celebrated in his profession, and asked what was my customary walk— I told him, on the Quay of the Neva to the foundery, or through the Newsky Perspective and round the Fontanka to the same Quay; which was a walk of between six and seven Wersts— He said that was sufficient for health— About two minutes after leaving the Emperor I met Count St: Julien & stop’d him— I told him that I had called at his Hotel a few days since to see him but had not found him at home. That Mr: John Spear Smith was going to Vienna and Paris—and I asked him if he could do me the favour to give him some letters for Vienna— Pour des lettres—said he—cela se pourroit difficilement—parceque depuis tous ces derniers Evenemens, Vienne n’est plus ce qu’il etoit— Rome n’est plus dans Rome, elle est toute—comme vous savéz— Mais pour un Passeport, volontiers— The Count’s invention is not very bright for reasons, to excuse himself for not giving letters; but I told him I should be much obliged to him for the Passport— On returning home I found Charles quite sick, and Mrs: Adams much alarmed for him— He has had a severe cold and cough for several days, and has now some fever— We sent for Dr: Galloway, who came and relieved us from much of our concern by assuring us that it was only a catarrh with a slight fever— The Dr: dined with us— Mrs: Adams took the child to her own chamber, and I had a bed made up on the Sopha, in my Cabinet and slept there.

23. Charles had a night of good rest, and is this day better— Mrs: Adams herself is quite unwell also— I was engaged all the time that I could bestow in writing— I received the notification that there would be a Court to morrow at Noon, at the Winter Palace; and an invitation to the Empress Mother’s Ball in the Evening at half past seven O’Clock— There came also a written Notification to Mrs: Adams, from the Commandeur de Maisonneuve, that she and her Sister Miss Johnson were both invited to the Ball— Mrs: Adams could not go; from the state of her health— It would not be proper according to the customs of the Country for Catherine to go alone; besides that never having been presented to the Empress-Mother, it would appear improper for her to attend her Ball— I called upon Monsieur de Maisonneuve, who told me that the Emperor had himself ordered that Miss Johnson’s name should be put upon the list of persons to be invited at the Court parties—and that the Empress-Mother invited no persons but such as were approved of by the Emperor. That Miss Johnson was therefore fully entitled to go, if she pleased; but that if she preferred to be presented to the Empresses before appearing at the Balls, he would take care to inform the Empress-Mother of the causes which prevented the attendance of either of the ladies, and he was confident that she would be gratified with it as a delicate attention. That before the next Ball, the Empress-Mother would be in town on some Sunday— That on the Evening before, Mrs: Adams could call with Catherine, at Countess Litta’s, and mention the wish of Catherine to be presented; and the next day, immediately after the Circle she would be presented to both the Empresses— And that the first time of the Empress Mother’s coming to town, he would give me notice of it.— Mr: Harris and Mr: J. S. Smith dined with us— I read this day a Sermon of Massillon, upon Afflictions— I was much pleased with it; but did not give it all the attention that it deserved— It made no deep impression upon my mind; and I think unless I read it again I shall remember nothing from it— I also read Robinson’s character of Elijah— From this writer I doubt whether I shall ever collect an idea worth remembering— Yet I continue reading his book because it seems to me the plan was susceptible of being usefully executed— I changed my bed again this night, and slept upon a Couchette, in our bed-chamber, without the partition.

24. It being the Emperor’s Birth-day between 12 and 1. O’Clock at Noon I went to the Winter Palace, and attended the Court there— Mr: J. S. Smith was presented to the Emperor and Empresses to take leave— The Circle was such as it always is— The Emperor told me that I should lose my walk to day.— The Empress-Mother told me she hoped she should see Mrs: Adams in the Evening at the Ball— I told her that I was afraid the state of her health would deprive her of that honour—which Her Majesty said she should much regret. But Monsieur de Maisonneuve had told me before that her Majesty had been informed that neither Mrs: Adams nor Catherine would be at the Ball, and of the reasons why; with which she was perfectly satisfied— The Empress said to me vôtre pays nous a fait un fâcheux Cadeau— I did not understand her— On dit (said she) que la fiévre jaune vient de paraitre en Italia— Ah! Madame, said I ce Cadeau là ne vient pas de chéz nous— C’est une Calomnie qu’on nous fait, Madame— Il vient d’Afrique— But said she, you have
the yellow-fever in your Country, every year, have you not— I told her I had not heard of it for four or five years, untill the last Summer— When the Empress pass’d on Baron Schladen, who stood next me said l’Imperatrice prend la peste pour la fievre Jaune— Mais vous vous ètes vaillamment defendu— The Court was over by two O’Clock— And about eight in the Evening I went alone; to the Ball.— It was as all these Balls are excessively tedious; though the Empress-Mother was very gracious, and extremely attentive to do the honours of her house— She twice express’d to me her regret at Mrs: Adams’s not being of the party— And also that Mademoiselle sa Soeur was not there— Mais pour cette jeune personne je suis sure que ce n’est rien que la timidité qui l’a empêché de venir— I stood the whole time untill Supper, which was served just about 12. at Night— The Emperor made some remark to me upon the warmth of the Rooms; which were indeed excessively warm. I had conversation with Count Soltykoff—Count de Maistre, Count Stedingk—Dr: Rogerson and the French Ambassador. Great part of the time I stood gazing, and doing nothing— It had been a great object of curiosity and anxiety with the other ministers to see whether the Empress and Grand-Duchess Ann would dance Polonaises with Count St: Julien.— They did not— They dance only with the French Ambassador, and he only sits at the Imperial table at supper— Count St: Julien has been here about a year, without any regular diplomatic character; and having no rule of etiquette to operate concerning him, has been invited to dine with the Emperor, and to the Hermitage parties— He has lately received and presented his credentials as Envoy-Extraordinary and Minister Plenipotentiary, a Minister of the second order— The Emperor has ordered that he should still be invited to the hermitage parties— At which several of the other Ministers of the same rank, none of whom receive such invitations have taken great offence, and have written about it to their Courts— St: Julien by his exultation at these distinctions, has aggravated the mortification of the others, and has countenanced a report which has been in circulation that he was in all respects to be treated with the same honours as an Ambassador; and even that there was a Convention between the Courts of Vienna and of St: Petersburg, by which this was reciprocally agreed.— He was however this Evening treated in no respect differently from the other Ministers of the second order— At our table, and next to me the Roman Catholic Archbishop of Mohiloff took his seat— It was not indeed his place; but the attendants suffered him to remain; and sitting next to him I had some conversation with him. When the Empress-mother, going the rounds of the tables, and speaking to every guest in turn came to him, she said to him with a smile, vous êtes ici sans doute pour la bénédiction— Pour la souhaiter, Madame, said he; puisque vôtre Majesté Impériale vent bien me le permettre— Upon my observing to him that the Greek Church was tolerant, he intimated to me that I was mistaken. the Government indeed said he is tolerant, and protects us—if they did not we should certainly be persecuted— He appeared to have some little knowledge of America; and told me that untill Bishop Carroll had been made an Archbishop, his diocese and his own, were he believed the two largest for extent of territory in the world.— After the supper, there was only a Polonaise danced, and the Imperial family retired about half-past one O’Clock in the morning— I was at home before two.

25. Count Stedingk last Evening promised me to give a Passport for Mr: Adams and Mr: Strong; for which I wrote him this day a Note— Mr: Adams called on me this morning to enquire if I was ready for his departure, but I was obliged to ask him to postpone it a day or two longer— I received a Note from Baron Campenhausen requesting me to call upon him to-morrow morning, which I promised to do— I dined with a Company principally of Americans at Mr: Meyer’s— Admiral Mordwinoff was there.— He is President of the section of the Council to which the questions respecting the admission of the American vessels have been referred, and he left us early in the Evening to attend a meeting of the members to decide upon some of the clearest cases submitted to them— I came home from Mr: Meyer’s early in the Evening, but could attend to no serious business after it— The usual dining hour here is five O’Clock, for all great Companies— The Custom is to carry all the dishes round in succession to all the Company, and the time of sitting at dinner is about two hours— There is a considerable variety of wines; but no drinking healths or toasts, and no sitting to drink after dinner— Mr: Meyer’s dinners are the most plentiful of any that I have met any where

26. According to appointment I called this morning upon Baron Campenhausen whom I found still unwell— I had about half an hour’s conversation with him, in which we went again over the subject of that which we had last week— He said that all the vessels had been arranged in different Classes according to the regularity of their documents, or of the Circumstances which might affect their right to admission— Those of the most unexceptionable Classes had now been selected, and would be admitted and allowed to dispose of their Cargoes. He said he would furnish me a list of them in the course of the day— Almost all the Americans were included in it.— I walked home, and coming round by the Quay met the Emperor— He stop’d, and asked me if I was not fatigued with the Ball— I told him no— He said he found it very long— I observed that the dancing Hall had been very warm— Mais, mon Dieu said he, que c’etoit long— J’aurois voulu le couper court de trois heures—au moins. I did not reply—for it might have been too uncourtly and even uncourteous, to have said how much I should have been willing to abridge it.— I dined at Count Romanzoff’s, and was within a few minutes of being too late— It was a great dinner of about sixty persons—in honour of the Emperor’s birth-day; though two days after the anniversary day— I saw there Admiral Mordwinoff; and told him what Baron Campenhausen had said to me of the vessels— But the Admiral said the business would still require the signature of the Emperor— I asked him whether that would be obtained to-morrow—he said, probably, but with a hesitation in his manner, which left a strong doubt upon my mind— In the Evening after returning home I sent the four Volumes of Dr: Rush’s Medical Inquiries and Observations, to Count Romanzoff, with a letter requesting that they might be presented to the Emperor, as from the author— Mr: Patterson was here part of the Evening. I received this day a Passport for Mr: Adams, and Mr Strong from Count Stedingk.

27. Though I am not yet satisfied with regard to the admission of the vessels, on account of which I have detained Mr: Adams for several days; yet I have concluded not to wait any longer— He called here this morning, and I agreed to have all my packets ready both for him and for Mr Strong this Evening— I accordingly made them all up and sent them, by Mr: W. S. Smith, who delivered them to him at his lodgings— He himself took with him the two Packets from Count Romanzoff to Count Pahlen— I received this morning from Baron Campenhausen the list of the vessels, which he had told me were decided upon, in favour of their admission— But he sent me at the same time a verbal message, that it was not yet official, as the Emperor’s signature was yet wanting— I enquired whether that would probably be given to day, and was told, probably— Mr: Harris, Mr: Montréal, Mr: Fisher, Mr: J. S. Smith, and Mr: Bridge were all here; and all wanting information concerning this decision, which I was not able to give them.— I wrote to Count Romanzoff, for a Passport for Mr: J. S. Smith, and his two Servants— He and Mr: Harris dined with us— I had a morning visit from Count Lüxbourg.

28. Mr: Adams and Mr: Strong went off early this morning— I received a Note from Count St: Julien with a letter for Mr: Smith to Count Matternich—and an Answer from Count Romanzoff to my note of yesterday, with a Passport for Mr: Smith, and with letters of recommendation for him to Count Lieven, the Russian Minister at Berlin; to Monsieur de Canicoff the Minister at Dresden—to Count Stakelberg the Minister at Vienna, and to Prince Kurakin the Ambassador at Paris; as I had requested. Mr: Jones who is also going to Vienna, though by a different road from that of Mr: Smith—that is, through Moscow and Kiew, asked me to apply for a Passport for him also to Count Romanzoff— But I understood the Count has not authority to give Passports, except for Courier’s and persons having relation to foreign missions, or to the department of foreign Affairs— Mr: Sonntag, an American Officer in the Navy, but now upon furlough called upon me this morning; he is just arrived from Stockholm, and is going, he says to Odessa— Mr: Woodward also called on me; and I advised him to see Mr: Grammann concerning Mr: Gray’s Brig Palafox, which is one of the vessels not included in the list sent to me by Baron Campenhausen— I had also a morning visit from Mr: Navarro.

29. Mr: J. S. Smith left the City this day at about 3. O’Clock P.M. for Berlin, Vienna and Paris; and Mr: Harris at about 10 O’Clock at Night for a tour to Archangel, and to Moscow— He had called in the morning with Mr: Moses of New-York, who arrived here a day or two since from Gothenburg, by the way of Hamburg— In the Evening I had a visit from General Watzdorf, to introduce a young Comte de Posen; who has just arrived, and is to be his Secretary of Legation— Catherine Johnson spent the Evening at Madame Colombi’s— Mrs: Adams did not go, having been bled this morning— I partly recovered the arrears of writing, which the business and the interruptions of the last fortnight have occasioned.— Mr: Moses gave me the first information that there has been a Call of Congress together, before the first Monday of December.

30. Mr: Jones took his departure this day at about 3. O’Clock in the afternoon. I walked this day earlier than usual to observe the setting of the Sun, and the extent of its Southern declination as apparent at the horizon— This was the day nearest to the solstice that I have been able to observe it; being the first day for nearly five weeks that it has been visible at the time of setting. And even now I could observe it only very imperfectly.— It sets at the Solstice at 46 minutes past 2. It rises so little above the horizon, that in the City, there is scarcely a Street where it can shine; and for a month before and after the winter solstice, the weather being always cloudy it is not much more light at Noon, than at the Summer Solstice at Midnight— I read this day Massillon’s Sermon upon the conception of the blessed Virgin—a festival kept in the Catholic Countries the 8th: of December. The divisions of this discourse are unusually artificial, but the discourse itself is excellent. The subject is miraculous purity—the instruction is the duty of purity— The following sentiment is strikingly just— Il n’y a pas loin entre la vertu qui se répose, et la vertu qui s’égare; et quand on ne fuit qu’à demi le vice, on est bien près de la retrouver encore sur ses pas— I also read Robinson’s character of Elisha.

31. Visits this morning from Mr: Montréal; Mr: Woodward, and Captain Towne. in the Evening from Mr: Bridge— Mr: Lohman also called in the morning— The Americans are all extremely uneasy respecting the Cargoes which have not yet been permitted to be sold, and all recur to me for information which I cannot give them.— I went this Evening to the Ball at the French Ambassador’s— The company as usual consisted of about 300 persons.— Besides the dancing of the Company, Mlle: George declaimed scenes from Iphigenia, Ariane and Phèdre— Monsieur d’Egligny read the collucutory parts— Mr: Duport and Miss George the younger danced several fancy dances, and among the rest the Russian dove dance, with accompaniments— I played whist with the two Messrs: Severin and Mr: Bacheracht, untill about 2. in the morning; but returned home before supper— I asked Mr: Gurjeff the Minister of Finance, whether the business of our ships was settled but he could not tell me.

Day— I seldom rise before full day-light; or in other words, during the present month before nine O’Clock— My first occupation is to read five chapters in the French Bible with Ostervald’s reflections— Write my journal of the preceding day; or any thing else that is urgent upon hand— Breakfast about eleven— From that time untill 3. p.m. I write, settle household or other accounts and pay, or much more frequently receive visits— The numbers of Americans now here, make this part of my time precarious for any steady employment— From three to five I usually walk—dine from five to seven— From seven untill eleven at Night, I pass in my chamber reading or writing as occasion requires— Or in Company abroad; or with Evening visitors at home— About Midnight is the hour for bed. By retiring from almost all the Societies which are commonly frequented here, which under my Circumstances I could not well avoid, I am able to lead a life more regular than that of the last Winter— I find however that I have very little real leisure upon my hands; and of that little I do not make a profitable use.

The year 1810 is past; and to all past time we are already dead— It has been to me rich with the blessings of Providence, for which I would be duly grateful to the giver of all good— Having been employed in the service of my Country, I am not conscious of its having witnessed any neglect in the performance of my official duties; nor can I charge myself with any intentional wrong in the private offices of life— But I have indulged too much indolence and inactivity of mind; and have not turned my leisure time to good account. I have pursued no object steadily; and the year has left no advantageous trace of itself in the annals of my life— I have formed my domestic establishment here in a very exact proportion to my means; but upon such an establishment a Public minister here can enjoy very little consideration, and must be subject to great animadversion— It is with great difficulty that I have hitherto adhered to my principles, and having now a full year’s experience, I think I shall be able to carry it through. I begin already to be sensible of the approaches of age. I cannot hope for any intellectual improvement upon my faculties from the present time— I pray for the power and the will to make a better improvement of them— And for the blessing of Heaven continually upon my Parents & my children—my wife, my brother, sister, and all connected with them—upon my native Country, and according to the will of the eternal disposer of Events upon the world of my fellow-creature man.
